author: mike.ferris
content: Hi everyone! I'm Mike from Buffalo, NY. Quick about me: I've been programming for 10 years across a few fields. I started out programming for satellites in C++/Python (1 launched running my code in 2018, another launches via SpaceX next year), then moved to doing corporate DevOps specializing in air-gapped environments, then launched a social iOS app, then realized decentralization is the future of finance so now I'm here! Looking forward to contributing and learning with everyone.

author: iamvadiraj
content: Hey everyone, I'm Vadiraj from India. I am a software developer and a researcher. I've written paper on the use cases of blockchain. My thesis in Masters was on blockchain based decentralised data storage systems. Now I am looking forward to contributing to Ethereum and learn a lot with all of you.

author: greg_vardy
content: Hey! I'm Greg, I'm a South African living in Cambridge (UK). I was doing a masters in maths here before I left to start a VR technology company, where we developed a novel deep learning architecture to generate photo-realistic 3D avatars from a single 2D photo, along with a custom renderer that allows for rendering photo-realistic virtual worlds on mobile GPU's.  We also integrated Ethereum into our platform (ERC20 and ERC721 tokens), allowing users to tokenize their virtual worlds and in-game art, which is what made me fall in love with Ethereum. We were acquired recently. I'm super interested in working on the EVM changes that need to be made for ETH2.

author: trent_vanepps
content: welcome! what sort of EVM changes have you been following?

author: greg_vardy
content:
Thanks Trent! Well maybe I should rephrase that from "changes that need to be made" to "changes that might be beneficial to make" haha. 
Specifically: https://github.com/ethereum/requests-for-proposals/blob/master/rfps/expand-address-to-32-bytes-implementation-and-spec-development.md,
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-3155-create-evm-trace-specification/5007/12,

author: greg_vardy
content:
Or maybe using SIMD to accelerate opcodes. But I guess that depends on what is happening with eWASM , because I think WASM currently only supports 128-bit SIMD. 

I've been trying to find some info on the state of eWASM, but it's been pretty difficult to catch up and find information. There doesn't seem to have been much activity around eWASM since 2020
